Abstract.

On-line chain partition is a two-player game between Spoiler and Algorithm. Spoiler presents a partially ordered set, point by point. Algorithm assigns incoming points (immediately and irrevocably) to the chains which constitute a chain partition of the order. The value of the game for orders of width wğ‘¤w is a minimum number valâ¡(w)valğ‘¤\operatorname{val}(w) such that Algorithm has a strategy using at most valâ¡(w)valğ‘¤\operatorname{val}(w) chains on orders of width at most wğ‘¤w. We analyze the chain partition game for up-growing semi-orders. Surprisingly, the golden ratio comes into play and the value of the game is âŒŠ1+52â€‹wâŒ‹152ğ‘¤\lfloor\frac{1+\sqrt{5}}{2}\;w\rfloor.

Key words and phrases:
on-line, chain partition, order, dimension, semi-order

1. Introduction

On-line chain partitions of an order can be described as a two-person game between Algorithm and Spoiler. The game is played in rounds. Spoiler presents an on-line order, one point at a time. Algorithm responds by making an irrevocable assignment of the new point to one of the chains of the chain partition. The performance of Algorithmâ€™s strategy is measured by comparing the number of chains used with the number of chains of an optimal chain partition. By Dilworthâ€™s Theorem the size of an optimal chain partition equals the width of the order. The value of the game for orders of width wğ‘¤w, denoted by valâ¡(w)valğ‘¤\operatorname{val}(w), is the least integer nğ‘›n for which some Algorithm has a strategy using at most nğ‘›n chains for every on-line order of width wğ‘¤w. Alternatively, it is the largest integer nğ‘›n for which Spoiler has a strategy that forces any Algorithm to use nğ‘›n chains on order of width wğ‘¤w.

The study of chain partition games goes back to the early 80â€™s when KiersteadÂ [4] (upper bound) and SzemerÃ©di (lower bound published in [5]) proved the estimates for on-line orders of width wğ‘¤w: (w+12)â©½valâ¡(w)â©½5wâˆ’14binomialğ‘¤12valğ‘¤superscript5ğ‘¤14\binom{w+1}{2}\leqslant\operatorname{val}(w)\leqslant\frac{5^{w}-1}{4}. It took almost 30 years until these bounds had been slightly improved. The story can be found in the surveyÂ [2].

The study of on-line chain partition on restricted classes of orders began in 1981 when Kierstead and Trotter [6] proved the following result: when Spoiler is restricted to presenting interval orders of width wğ‘¤w, the value of the game is 3â€‹wâˆ’23ğ‘¤23w-2. Among other classes of orders that have been studied thereafter are (ğ¤+ğ¤)ğ¤ğ¤(\mathbf{k+k})-free orders and semi-orders. Again we refer toÂ [2] for details.

Up-growing on-line orders have been introduced by FelsnerÂ [3]. In this variant Spoilerâ€™s power is restricted by the condition that the new element has to be a maximal element of the order presented so far. FelsnerÂ [3] showed that the value of the chain partition game on up-growing orders is (w+12)binomialğ‘¤12\binom{w+1}{2}. The case of up-growing interval orders was resolved by Baier, Bosek and MicekÂ [1]. The value of the game in this variant is 2â€‹wâˆ’12ğ‘¤12w-1.

This paper resolves the on-line chain partition problem for up-growing semi-orders. An order ğğ\mathbf{P} is called a semi-order if it has a unit interval representation, i.e., there exists a mapping Iğ¼I of points of the order into unit length intervals on a real line so that x<yğ‘¥ğ‘¦x<y in ğğ\mathbf{P} iff interval Iâ€‹(x)ğ¼ğ‘¥I(x) is entirely to the left of Iâ€‹(y)ğ¼ğ‘¦I(y). Alternatively semi-orders are characterized as the (ğŸ+ğŸ)22\mathbf{(2+2)} and (ğŸ‘+ğŸ)31\mathbf{(3+1)}-free orders (see Fig.Â 2).

Considering on-line chain partitions of semi-orders note that the general (not up-growing) case is easy to analyze: First, observe that the number of chains used by Algorithm can be bounded by 2â€‹wâˆ’12ğ‘¤12w-1. Let xğ‘¥x be the new point and consider the set Incâ¡(x)Incğ‘¥\operatorname{Inc}(x) of points incomparable with xğ‘¥x. Clearly, the only chains forbidden for xğ‘¥x are those used in Incâ¡(x)Incğ‘¥\operatorname{Inc}(x). Now widthâ¡(Incâ¡(x))â©½wâˆ’1widthIncğ‘¥ğ‘¤1\operatorname{width}(\operatorname{Inc}(x))\leqslant w-1 since the width of the whole order does not exceed wğ‘¤w. Moreover, heightâ¡(Incâ¡(x))â©½2heightIncğ‘¥2\operatorname{height}(\operatorname{Inc}(x))\leqslant 2 as the presented order is (ğŸ‘+ğŸ)31\mathbf{(3+1)}-free. Therefore, |Incâ¡(x)|â©½2â€‹(wâˆ’1)=2â€‹wâˆ’2Incğ‘¥2ğ‘¤12ğ‘¤2|\operatorname{Inc}(x)|\leqslant 2(w-1)=2w-2, proving that xğ‘¥x can be assigned to at least one of 2â€‹wâˆ’12ğ‘¤12w-1 legal chains.

It turns out that there is no better strategy for Algorithm. In other words, Spoiler may force Algorithm to use 2â€‹wâˆ’12ğ‘¤12w-1 chains on semi-orders of width wğ‘¤w. A strategy for Spoiler looks as follows:

  1. (1)

    Present two antichains Ağ´A and BğµB, both consisting of wğ‘¤w points in such a way that A<Bğ´ğµA<B, i.e., all points from Ağ´A are below all points from BğµB. If Algorithm uses 2â€‹wâˆ’12ğ‘¤12w-1 or more chains, the construction is finished. Otherwise, suppose that kğ‘˜k chains (2â©½kâ©½w2ğ‘˜ğ‘¤2\leqslant k\leqslant w) contain elements from Ağ´A andÂ BğµB, namely let aiâˆˆAisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ´ğ‘–a_{i}\in A_{i}, biâˆˆBisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğµğ‘–b_{i}\in B_{i} for 1â©½iâ©½k1ğ‘–ğ‘˜1\leqslant i\leqslant k lie in the same chain.

  2. (2)

    Present kâˆ’1ğ‘˜1k-1 points x1,â€¦,xkâˆ’1subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜1x_{1},\ldots,x_{k-1} in such a way that {a1,â€¦,ai}â©½xiâ©½{bi+1,â€¦,bk}subscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜\left\{a_{1},\ldots,a_{i}\right\}\leqslant x_{i}\leqslant\left\{b_{i+1},\ldots,b_{k}\right\} and xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i} is incomparable to all the rest (the interval representation of the whole order looks as in Fig.Â 1). It is easy to verify that in such setting Algorithm is forced to use 2â€‹wâˆ’12ğ‘¤12w-1 chains.

The contribution of this paper is the following theorem.

Theorem 1.1.

The value of the on-line chain partition game for up-growing semi-orders of width wğ‘¤w is âŒŠ1+52â‹…wâŒ‹â‹…152ğ‘¤\lfloor\frac{1+\sqrt{5}}{2}\cdot w\rfloor.

2. Up-growing Semi-orders

2.1. Outline

In this section we prove that the value of the on-line chain partition game for up-growing semi-orders equals âŒŠÏ†â‹…wâŒ‹â‹…ğœ‘ğ‘¤\lfloor\varphi\cdot w\rfloor, where Ï†=1+52ğœ‘152\varphi=\frac{1+\sqrt{5}}{2} is the golden number. First, in Sect.Â 2.2 we collect some facts about semi-orders. Section 2.3 describes a strategy for Spoiler which forces Algorithm to use at least âŒŠÏ†â‹…wâŒ‹â‹…ğœ‘ğ‘¤\lfloor\varphi\cdot w\rfloor chains on a semi-order of width wğ‘¤w. This sets the lower bound for the value of the game. In Sect.Â 2.4 we propose a strategy for Algorithm using at most âŒŠÏ†â‹…wâŒ‹â‹…ğœ‘ğ‘¤\lfloor\varphi\cdot w\rfloor chains on semi-orders of width at most wğ‘¤w.

The presence of the golden number Ï†ğœ‘\varphi in the result of a chain partition game may seem surprising. In fact, it is the Fibonacci sequence (F0=0subscriptğ¹00F_{0}=0, F1=1subscriptğ¹11F_{1}=1 and Fi+2=Fi+Fi+1subscriptğ¹ğ‘–2subscriptğ¹ğ‘–subscriptğ¹ğ‘–1F_{i+2}=F_{i}+F_{i+1}) which appears in the counting argument of the upper bound and serves as a discrete counterpart of Ï†ğœ‘\varphi.

An order ğğ\mathbf{P} is called an interval order if it has an interval representation, i.e., there exists a mapping Iğ¼I of points of the order into intervals on a real line so that x<yğ‘¥ğ‘¦x<y in ğğ\mathbf{P} iff maxâ¡Iâ€‹(x)<minâ¡Iâ€‹(y)ğ¼ğ‘¥ğ¼ğ‘¦\max I(x)<\min I(y). 2.4. The Upper Bound

Consider a semi-order ğ=(P,â©½)ğğ‘ƒ\mathbf{P}=(P,\leqslant) with P=(a,b,c,d,e)ğ‘ƒğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘‘ğ‘’P=(a,\,b,\,c,\,d,\,e) and the chain partition Î“:Pâˆ–{e}â†’â„•:Î“â†’ğ‘ƒğ‘’â„•\Gamma:P\setminus\left\{e\right\}\rightarrow\mathbb{N} as shown in Fig.Â 3.

Point eğ‘’e may be covered with a new chain (say, with number 444) or with one of the chains already used. In the latter case Algorithm may choose between 222 and 333. We say that chain Î±ğ›¼\alpha is valid for a new pointÂ xğ‘¥x extending an already partitioned order ğğ\mathbf{P}Â if xğ‘¥x dominates all points fromÂ Î±ğ›¼\alpha in ğğ\mathbf{P}. We claim that among the valid chains 222 and 333 defining Î“â€‹(e)=3Î“ğ‘’3\Gamma(e)=3 is the better choice. Indeed, any future point pğ‘p presented by Spoiler and dominating cğ‘c will also dominate bğ‘b (otherwise, ğğ\mathbf{P}Â would have a (ğŸ+ğŸ)22\mathbf{(2+2)}Â configuration which is forbidden in interval orders). On the other hand, Spoiler may play qğ‘q greater than bğ‘b but remaining incomparable toÂ cğ‘c (see Fig.Â 4).

Hence, using the chain of cğ‘c for eğ‘’e leaves more options for the future. Whenever the chains of two points xğ‘¥x and yğ‘¦y are valid and xâ†‘âŠŠyâ†‘x\oUpset\subsetneq y\oUpset then it seems safer to use the chain of xğ‘¥x. Our Algorithm ALG will go along this intuition.

Suppose that Spoiler introduces a semi-order ğ=(P,â©½)ğğ‘ƒ\mathbf{P}=(P,\leqslant) with a presentation order P=(p1,â€¦,pn)ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘›P=(p_{1},\ldots,p_{n}). We refer to the chains used by ALG as ALG-chains or just chains. With ğxsubscriptğğ‘¥\mathbf{P}_{x} we denote the order consisting of all points presented prior to xğ‘¥x. We say that a chain Î±ğ›¼\alpha is valid for point xğ‘¥x if topâ¡(Î±)topğ›¼\operatorname{top}(\alpha) in ğxsubscriptğğ‘¥\mathbf{P}_{x} is below xğ‘¥x in ğğ\mathbf{P}. The options of ALG are to put xğ‘¥x into some valid chain or into a new chain. We are ready to describe Algorithmâ€™s strategy. Let xğ‘¥x be a new point presented by Spoiler.

Algorithm ALG:If there is a valid chain for xğ‘¥x, then put xğ‘¥x into a valid chain Î±ğ›¼\alpha such that top(Î±)â†‘âŠ†top(Î²)â†‘\operatorname{top}(\alpha)\oUpset\subseteq\operatorname{top}(\beta)\oUpset in ğxsubscriptğğ‘¥\mathbf{P}_{x} for all valid chains Î²ğ›½\beta. Otherwise, if there is no valid chain, use a new chain for xğ‘¥x.

ALG is a greedy algorithm, i.e., it uses a new chain only when it is left with no other option. Note also that ALG has some freedom in choosing a chain for a new point xğ‘¥x as there may be many tops of valid chains for xğ‘¥x with the same minimum up set in ğxsubscriptğğ‘¥\mathbf{P}_{x}.

The bound on the performance of ALG on width wğ‘¤w is stated in the following proposition. This is the upper bound part for TheoremÂ 1.1.
